data.title: Tegan and Sara Break Down Their Music Career, 'L Word' Appearance & New Show 'High School'
data.meta_description:
"To this day, gay people will come up to me and say 'Dana Fairbanks is gay.' And I am so proud to be a part of that moment." Tegan and Sara look back on some of their shared life highlights. From the time their album 'So Jealous' made Rolling Stones Top 50 records of the year and they both got baby bangs to remaking Coldplay's "Yellow" music video with their own song "Yellow," here are a few of the moments that shaped both Tegan's and Sara's identities, lives and music careers.
Director: Emily Geraghty
Director of Photography: Ben Dewey
Editor: Jess Lane, Brittany Lewis
Creative Producer: Efrat Kashai
Line Producer: Jen Santos
Associate Producer: Jessica Gordon
Production Manager: Mark Bond
Production Coordinator: Jamal Colvin
Director, Video Talent: Lauren Mendoza
Camera Operator: Chris Alfonso
Audio: Rehanna Chandan
Production Assistant: Griffin Garnett
Gaffer: Niklas Moller
Hair & Make-Up: Yevgene Wright-Mason, Maria Walton
Post Production Supervisor: Christian Olguin
Post Production Coordinator: Scout Alter
Supervising Editor: Erica Dillman
Assistant Editor: Billy Ward
data.text:
Remember photographers used to love

to put our faces together?

They'd be like,

Can you put the tips of your noses together?

And Sara was the one

that finally started to set boundaries.

This is a fun interview.

Yeah, it's like trauma dumping.

We're like, And then Sara said,

'Would you ask Radiohead to do this?'

Hi, I'm Tegan.

I'm Sara.

And today, we are taking a look back

at some moment that shaped our career and identity.

This is Becoming Tegan and Sara.

[Tegan and Sara playing guitar]

So this is in our senior year of high school.

What I sort of know would happen shortly after this clip

is that we would really launch our music career

where people wanted to already begin shaping us.

We were not out in the clip.

We both had started to explore our identity

and we both sort of understood that we were probably gay.

We would've said gay back then, not queer.

But it was gonna still be probably almost another year

before we would actually,

well before I would actually come out to people.

Journalists would be like,

So, are you writing about your boyfriends?

What do your boyfriends think?

And it just made me feel nuts.

Super weird.

Even though we were teenagers, we were 18 years old,

I don't even know very many 18 year olds

that wanna talk about their sex lives

or their romantic lives with 45 year old men.

Especially as I got into my senior year of high school

when I started to secretly date my best friend

who was a girl, you can feel the songs really changing.

Leading up to that point, I'm not sure.

We had songs like Gregory,

which was about a boy who freezes to death,

which is definitely about acid.

Basically we went through a psychedelic stage

where it was sort of like The Grateful Dead,

and then we just went through our gay stage.

Yeah, 10th grade is psychedelics,

11th grade is the struggle to get off psychedelics

and then 12th grade is gay love.

If It Was You was an album

I think that kind of actually launched

the Tegan and Sara sound.

Before that, we had sort of been struggling to figure out

exactly who we were, what we wanted to sound like.

And to me, it was sort of a return to kind of our roots.

We'd grown up listening to a lot

of rock music and punk music,

and If It Was You just had a snotty, punky style.

Just, it corresponds in my mind

with the time where we really became ourselves.

Hi, my hair.

Hi, I'm Sara and I'm from Tegan and Sara

and this is our European trip.

What this video is is that Sara and I filmed everything.

This is, remember, it's 2002.

It's pre-YouTube, pre-influencers, pre-social media.

We got signed when we were 19

and all our friends went off to college

and we wouldn't see people.

We couldn't talk to anyone and we didn't have cell phones,

we didn't have the ability to stay in touch,

and so we filmed everything.

And then I would come home

and I would edit together these videos.

We would put it up on our website.

And six people would find it.

Yeah, but I can remember our managers being like,

You're paying so much money for hosting all of this data.

It's sweet.

I mean, we're on tour in Europe and then into the States,

and you can just see us deteriorate over this clip

and we just get more and more exhausted looking.

It's the receipts that we really paid our dues.

We did it.

Now artists are like, Oh my God, touring is so exhausting.

Our bus broke down.

And I'm like, a bus?

You just put out your first album!

It took us eight years to get to a bus.

We put out our album So Jealous in 2004.

That was our fourth record.

It was the record where we both sort of felt

like we were legitimately being accepted as a band.

All of a sudden, places like Rolling Stone and Spin

were having us into their offices to meet with journalists.

Rolling Stone ended up saying

So Jealous was one of the top 50 records of that year.

It just felt legitimate. It was a big year.

We both got bangs.

[Tegan] We both got baby bangs actually.

Spin had written this terrible review

and called us Wiccan-folk nightmares.

It was actually being accepted by straight men

that made the media stop ignoring us,

because they had to listen to the men

that they deemed important.

So Jack White from The White Stripes

covered Walking With A Ghost from So Jealous

and it was like, White Stripes were worshiped

by these magazines.

Out of context, it feels really sad

when you really dissect it and magnify it,

but in content in that moment, it was overnight.

Yeah, people started to talk about us.

It was just like we were legitimate.

We were just like, oh we're in a band.

It felt like we were maybe having to convince people less

that we were real.

We were still shrugging off that early age affiliation

with teen singers,

or this idea that we had been put together

by a record company.

It took years to convince people, which is exhausting,

but I think this was the record

where people were like, Okay.

Oh yeah, I know what this is.

[Tegan and Sara performing]

Speaking of trauma dumping.

I believe this was from the third season of The L Word.

It shot up in Vancouver.

We had been hearing rumors

that there was a show about lesbians.

I didn't have cable, I was living in Montreal.

I knew one couple who seemed very rich to me at the time.

I remember they had cable,

but they would record each episode weekly

and then they would give the VHS tapes

to me and my girlfriend at the time.

And then I remember we brought it on tour

and Tegan had not seen it, so we were like,

We have something to show you.

And we would all crowd onto our tour bus

and we would watch these bootleg versions of The L Word.

It was a joy, it was a total joy.

It was super cool.

When we read the script

and the portrayal of them on drugs, I remember thinking,

None of these people have ever done drugs before,

and that's clear from re-watching the clip.

Do you know who's a lesbian?

Dana Fairbanks.

To this day, gay people will come up to me and be like,

Dana Fairbanks is gay.

Still people say that to me all the time

and I think it's like,

I'm so proud to be a part of that moment.

♪ A million hours left to think of you and think of that ♪

The music video for The Con,

which was from the album The Con, came out in 2007.

We actually shot this video,

it was the day before our 27th birthday,

and I know this because I was so profoundly depressed.

My girlfriend had broken up with me

and I had cried the whole night before shooting the video.

The hair and makeup and wardrobe team felt so sorry for me

that they gave me a pair of Paul Smith sneakers

for my birthday.

And our mullets are on point.

[Sara] Our mullets are so sleek.

We look like seals.

It's like, there's almost a sheen.

[Tegan] They're beautiful. I wanna pet us.

[Tegan] Yeah. Very on point, and actually,

I really really loved my T-shirt in this video

and it's just a good reminder to myself

that I just should stop...

Stop giving away your clothes.

Why do I always give away my clothes,

'cause I would love to have that T-shirt still.

The record was about anxiety.

I talked to the video director, Suzie, and was just like,

I just told her how anxious I was

about absolutely everything, and I just loved her treatment.

It just, especially the end

where I'm drowning in the bathtub.

It was also very stressful to pretend to drown,

but it's pretty awesome to watch.

For us, even though we were indie rock,

there was so much emo in us,

and the emo world was much more,

they embraced us so much more than the indie rock world did.

It's a record that so many people refer to

as a beloved Tegan and Sara record,

but it was actually kind of a slow burn.

The first six months of that record cycle,

we used to play the record start to finish

and then we would play it backwards.

We'd play it from song one to 14

and then play 14 to one for the same audience.

We were like, You're gonna love the record, trust me.

You just need to listen to it twice.

While we are being so blatantly candid and open

with our audience, it's a double edged sword

because you cannot all of a sudden be like,

Well I don't wanna talk about my sexuality.

We got more formal about our activism in 2007, 2008.

I remember probably it coinciding with Obama, Prop 8.

Instead of it being a question of,

So you guys are gay?

Do you write your songs about girls?

Tell me more.

It was like, So you guys are gay,

what do you think about what's happening politically

in the United States or around the world

when it comes to LGBTQ rights?

It sort of required us to adopt more language

and more of a position, I guess you could say,

which felt really natural.

We thought of ourselves and our concerts as safe spaces.

We weren't using that phrase,

but we'd go through Tulsa

or we'd go through Columbus or Kansas City,

and we knew that we were a gay happening.

Yeah, that was an exciting time.

I felt like that was actually the start, for me,

of kind of empowering ourselves as not just gay musicians,

but we became, I think, important leaders

in the queer movement within the music industry.

♪ All I wanna get is ♪

♪ A little bit closer ♪

Oh my God, we're skipping Sainthood.

Can I just publicly say, we are skipping Sainthood,

which is my favorite Tegan and Sara album,

which is probably saying a lot.

I've always been known in the industry as deep cut Sara.

I think the evolution from The Con into Sainthood

into Heartthrob felt like we could distinguish ourselves

from what people thought we were still.

Women especially, we just get boxed in

and Sara and I felt very much

like we didn't wanna be told what to do.

And we were on a major label and they were basically like,

You have your lane. And we were like, Well we wanna work

with the biggest pop producer in the world

and we wanna make a huge record.

It was a concerted effort that we made

to go in a different direction, but to be perfectly honest,

it was just, I wrote Closer,

and when you write something that is undeniably pop,

it's four on the floor, the hook is right off the top.

When I sent it to Sara, she wrote me back 10 minutes later

and said, This is a hit.

♪ Here comes the breath before we get a little bit closer ♪

The video felt like, it was one of the first times

I remember feeling like the record label was meddling.

I remember having a lot of fights with the label

and with our managers at the time.

It was just this emphasis on,

Well you're so feminine and you're so pretty

and you're so different than what people think queer is,

and it was just, we knew what that language meant.

The original stylist who had been booked showed up

and there were tank tops and things like that,

and my girlfriend at the time called a friend of hers

who was dressing Hayley from Paramore at the time

and she came in last minute, opened up our suitcases

and brought a few items of her own and dressed us,

because we were like,

Oh my God, we're not gonna wear tank tops in the video.

I think we were one of the first bands

that also was tapping into something

that maybe didn't actually look like our lives.

These were sort of coded ways

of saying we're queering something we've all seen before,

the sort of high school movie vibe at a party,

but we're gonna make it gay.

I think it's better having it be our secret.

Totally.

We wanted to write a book about the late 90s

when we were 15, 16 and 17.

We pitched it, we wrote a proposal,

and then all of a sudden we had a book

that we needed to write.

Almost immediately when we started writing the book,

we were like, This will make a totally cool TV show.

It was a really amazing journey.

We shot the show this last spring in Calgary,

where we grew up.

We actually shot in our high school

where we went to high school.

I don't know if I think of it

as being highly fictionalized.

I think it's the Tegan and Sara story.

I just, I never got to see teenagers play guitar

or learn how to play guitar, girls.

These formative moments of struggling with my identity

but also falling in love and having a sexual relationship

with my best friend that I had to keep under wraps,

to see that come alive on screen was just so moving to me.

And I think the show captures that sort of feeling

of when you first realize that you're gay

and it's not just falling in love with one person,

it's like the possibility of love is everywhere.

But often with gay stories, we only get to see,

Bill realizes that he loves Ted, and then...

Bill and Ted?

It's one on one to one or something.

I don't know, just throwing out some big names, whatever.

But when I was gay and a teenager,

I kinda felt like I was falling in love

with every girl that I saw

and every girl I was friends with.

I think it also captures the drug experience

better than the other show we were talking about.

Crybaby is a lot like Sainthood, actually.

Just kidding.

It feels like a bit of an experimental record for us.

It's our 10th album and I sort of have this nervousness

or this insecurity, how many more albums can a band make

after they've made 10?

Thinking about how you're gonna keep people

excited and invested, even though there's albums

that they already really really love

and songs that they return to.

How do you compete with that?

So I feel like we gave it our best shot.

I think it's a really strong album, start to finish.

♪ We hit play, feels like yesterday ♪

When we were coming up with an idea

for the Yellow music video,

I was pitching all these extremely complicated,

extremely expensive ideas, and Sara wrote back and said,

Might be too on the nose,

but should we just remake Coldplay's 'Yellow' video

in our own way?

It could be kinda cool 'cause there was one of him

but there's two of us.

Anyway, it ended up working out perfectly

because in his video, Chris Martin's walking up the beach

and it's raining.

It had been blazing hot in Vancouver all week

and then the day that we shot this at 4:30 in the morning,

it started to rain, so we're soaking wet on the beach.

It was as if the heavens above opened up and were like,

Yes, two bands can have a song called 'Yellow',

different songs but have the same video.

I dare to say, I see a legacy.

Because of what we did and the road we walked,

I see bands now coming out or artists coming out

that may not even have heard of Tegan and Sara,

but I know that our legacy is that those bands get exposure

in ways that they wouldn't have 20 years ago,

that people's minds were changed in important ways

to make space for those kinds of artists

and those kinds of bands.

I don't think ever about myself

as an iconic lesbian artist.

Those words definitely don't,

I think it's probably best,

even if people think you're an icon,

to never think of yourself as one.

Like when your wife is mad at you and you're like,

I'm an icon. Do you know who you're talking to?

Yeah, I just, I don't

because I still feel like that Tegan in 1998

outside of her high school

with the middle part and the K Way jacket.

I just feel like I'm 18.

Thank you so much to everyone who watched.

Thanks for having us.

Yes, this was Becoming with Tegan and Sara.

Or Becoming Tegan and Sara.

Is this Becoming Tegan and Sara? Do we dress people now

and get them into outfits that look like us?

Becoming Tegan and Sara, a new show on HGTV.

Yeah.

Become Tegan and Sara because they're too old to do this now

and they would like younger people to do it.

[light music]
